pageData.text: The environment contains many foreign substances that are potentially harmful to the human body, such as microbes and animal- and plant-derived substances like toxins and venoms. The human body has several layers of defense. The first layer of defense is the <button class='glossary-text'>skin</button>; the second is the <button class='glossary-text'>lymphatic system</button>; and the third is the immune system. This investigation examines the anatomy and physiology of the lymphatic system and the immune responses of the human body to infection.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation - 5 minutes
Activity 1: Determining Rate of Diffusion - 60 minutes
Activity 2: Simulated Immune Reaction - 60 minutes

pageData.title: Overview Video: Lymphatic System and Immunity
Outcomes
text: Understand the relationship between the form and function of the .
Explore the different layers of defense in the human body.
Examine the functions of the immune response.

pageData.subTitle: Hazard pictograms

pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>lymphatic system</button> is part of the immune system. One of the most important functions of the immune system is to help fight infections caused by microbes and viruses. The human body contains approximately 30 trillion human cells. However, it is estimated that the human microbiome (the collection of bacteria, viruses, and fungi that live symbiotically in and on the body) contains over 39 trillion microbial cells. So how does the immune system know which microbes are beneficial and which ones are harmful?

Research suggests that our immune system is taught by the beneficial microbes of our body not to attack them. We inherit much of our microbiome from our mothers during childbirth, and it plays a critical role in keeping us healthy throughout our lives. Our gut microbiome helps us digest food, absorb nutrients, break down toxins, and synthesize vitamins. Our microbiome also helps fight off pathogenic organisms, especially on our <button class='glossary-text'>skin</button>. When our skin microbiota are healthy and balanced, our skin also appears healthy.

pageData.desc: A stylized illustration of bacteria picture-in-picture with the human digestive system.
pageData.altText: A stylized illustration of bacteria picture-in-picture with the human digestive system.

pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>lymphatic</button> system plays a vital role in the body’s immunity. Lymphatic vessels transport <button class='glossary-text'>lymph</button>, a fluid containing infection-fighting white blood cells, from body tissues into lymph ducts that drain into <button class='glossary-text'>lymph nodes</button>.

<button class='glossary-text'>Tonsils</button> are in the back of the throat, on both sides. Tonsils aid in fighting off <button class='glossary-text'>pathogens</button> but sometimes become infected. A <button class='glossary-text'>tonsillectomy</button> can be performed to remove infected tonsils.
Lymphocytes are a type of white blood cell that produces antibodies for immunity.
The <button class='glossary-text'>thymus</button> is a lymphatic organ located between the lungs and acts as storage for lymphocytes.

pageData.subTitle: Lymph Nodes
pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Lymph nodes</button> are small, oval-shaped nodes that occur in clusters throughout the body. They contain lymphocytes and help defend the body against infection.
Superficial lymph nodes are highly concentrated in the cervical (neck), axillary (arm pit), and inguinal (groin) regions. These are palpable and are often used as indicators of infection.

pageData.subTitle: Spleen
pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>spleen</button> a lymphatic organ located in the upper abdomen, behind the stomach. Its function is to filter blood’s debris and old red blood cells. Lymphocytes are also stored here.

pageData.subTitle: Lymphatic System
pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>cardiovascular system</button> transports various fluids throughout the body. This system has small capillaries through which liquid leaves the cardiovascular system and moves into and between cells. This liquid carries nutrients and oxygen to the cells. Although some of the liquid that has left the cardiovascular system will return to it, some will also remain in the space between cells. This liquid must be returned to the blood in order to prevent its build up in the extremities. The body has a complex network of vessels and ducts to move this interstitial liquid from the extremities and back to the core of the body. This is the <button class='glossary-text'>lymphatic system</button> (see Figure 1). The lymphatic system extends throughout the body. Most of the lymphatic ducts are located close to the <button class='glossary-text'>skin</button> and on the surface of the muscles. Movement of the muscles pushes liquid through the ducts. This liquid, collected from the interstitial fluid, is called <button class='glossary-text'>lymph</button>. Valves located in these ducts prevent the lymph from flowing away from the core. These one-way valves function similarly to valves found in the heart and veins of the cardiovascular system (see Figure 2).

image.desc: Figure 1: Illustration showing the lymphatic system and its components
image.altText: Figure 1: Illustration showing the lymphatic system and its components

image.desc: Figure 2: Diagram showing the details of a lymphatic vessel
image.altText: Figure 2: Diagram showing the details of a lymphatic vessel

pageData.text: The movement of <button class='glossary-text'>lymph</button> through this complex system of ducts is slow. At regular intervals throughout the body, the ducts of the <button class='glossary-text'>lymphatic system</button> come together in <button class='glossary-text'>lymph nodes</button>. These nodes filter the fluid running through them and remove contaminants. Lymph nodes are located throughout the body, but some of the most commonly recognized lymphoid nodules are the <button class='glossary-text'>tonsils</button>. The tonsils are collections of partially encapsulated lymphoid nodules and are part of the mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue, or <button class='glossary-text'>MALT</button>, which will be discussed in more detail below. True lymph nodes are fully encapsulated, bean-shaped organs, as shown in Figure 3. True lymph nodes are distributed along the course of the lymphatic vasculature. The outer layer of the lymph node is called the <button class='glossary-text'>cortex</button>, and the inner region is called the <button class='glossary-text'>medulla</button>. Lymph enters the node via afferent lymphatic vessels and drains into the medulla through a complex series of sinuses. The lymph eventually drains into the hilum and from there leaves the lymph node through efferent lymphatic vessels on its return to the core of the body).

pageData.desc: Figure 3: Illustration showing the anatomy of a lymph node and its components
pageData.altText: Figure 3: Illustration showing the anatomy of a lymph node and its components

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Lymph nodes are located throughout the body, but some of the most recognized lymphoid nodules are the tonsils.

pageData.subTitle: Immune System
pageData.text: The body employs several means to defend itself from <button class='glossary-text'>pathogens</button> (disease-causing microorganisms or viruses) and potently harmful foreign substances. The first component of the body’s defense system is comprised of the <button class='glossary-text'>skin</button> and other <button class='glossary-text'>epithelial tissues</button>, such as the mucous membranes. These tissues keep foreign substances from entering the body, thus preventing them from causing harm. This first layer of defense can be breached, however, by ingestion, through a wound, or any other situation that enables a foreign substance to enter the body. Because the <button class='glossary-text'>lymphatic system</button> is spread throughout the body and is located close to the skin, it is very likely that pathogens will enter the body through the lymphatic system. The <button class='glossary-text'>lymph</button> will carry these pathogens to the <button class='glossary-text'>lymph nodes</button>, where they will either be filtered out or encounter the second layer of defense. Because of their role in eliminating pathogens, lymph nodes are tightly clustered in areas where pathogen entry is more likely. One such area is around the <button class='glossary-text'>pharynx</button>. Here, both the nasal and oral passages come together, increasing the likelihood of pathogens entering the body.

The group of lymph nodes located around the pharynx have a special name, mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue commonly known as <button class='glossary-text'>MALT</button>. Another area where pathogens  commonly enter the body is the gut. A special group of lymph nodes is located there, the gut-associated lymphoid tissue, commonly known as <button class='glossary-text'>GALT</button>. Both the MALT and GALT are centers of the body’s second layer of defense, the <button class='glossary-text'>non-specific immune responses</button>, or <button class='glossary-text'>innate immune system</button>. One of the first reactions of the body to pathogen entry is to increase the temperature at the infection site. Because most pathogens function optimally in the body, their proteins are designed to function at normal body temperature and may be disrupted at higher temperatures. The body also redirects a certain class of large white blood cells, called <button class='glossary-text'>monocytes</button>, to the infected area. Monocytes engulf the pathogens in a process called <button class='glossary-text'>phagocytosis</button>. Should this nonspecific response fail to eliminate the pathogen, a third defensive component, known as the <button class='glossary-text'>specific immune response</button> or <button class='glossary-text'>adaptive immune system</button>, will be activated. These monocytes, phagocytes, and <button class='glossary-text'>leukocytes</button> are located in the <button class='glossary-text'>cardiovascular system</button>. Other phagocytes patrol the area outside the cardiovascular system for foreign substances.

Pathogenic microorganisms have specific proteins on their outer membrane called <button class='glossary-text'>antigens</button>, or antibody generators. The immune system recognizes an antigen as not being part of the body and will therefore begin producing specific <button class='glossary-text'>antibodies</button> against the antigen. Antibodies are highly specific protein molecules that typically only recognize one particular antigen.

<button class='glossary-text'>B lymphocytes</button> (or <button class='glossary-text'>B cells</button>) and <button class='glossary-text'>T lymphocytes</button> (or <button class='glossary-text'>T cells</button>) are two types of <button class='glossary-text'>leukocytes</button> that are pre-programmed to bind to specific antigens via receptors embedded in their cell membranes. Both types of lymphocytes are produced in red bone marrow. B cells remain in the bone marrow until they have undergone a maturation process and are ready to enter the cardiovascular and <button class='glossary-text'>lymphatic systems</button>. T cells leave the bone marrow and mature in the <button class='glossary-text'>thymus</button> (a lymphoid organ located just in front of the heart) before being released into circulation. Lymphoid tissues and organs, including <button class='glossary-text'>lymph</button> nodes, house large numbers of mature B and T cells, each specific to a particular antigen.

When a B cell recognizes and binds to its specific antigen, it internalizes and digests the molecule and then displays the antigen fragments on its surface. A special type of T cell, called a <button class='glossary-text'>T helper cell</button>, recognizes the displayed antigen and stimulates the B cell to divide, generating a group of genetically identical progeny cells with specificity for the same antigen. The progeny cells are known as <button class='glossary-text'>clones</button>. Some of the clones differentiate into <button class='glossary-text'>plasma cells</button>, which secrete antigen-specific antibodies. When these antibodies bind to their specific antigen on the surface of a <button class='glossary-text'>pathogen</button>, the invasion of body tissues is hindered, and the pathogens are rendered more readily recognizable to phagocytes. It is important to note that some of the newly formed B cells become <button class='glossary-text'>memory B cells</button>. Memory B cells persist for a long period of time, enabling a strong and rapid response if the same antigen that led to their formation enters the body again.

There are several different categories of <button class='glossary-text'>T cells</button> in addition to the <button class='glossary-text'>T helper cells</button>. For example, <button class='glossary-text'>cytotoxic T cells</button> directly attack and destroy cells bearing foreign  <button class='glossary-text'>antigens</button> on their surfaces, such as virus-infected or cancer cells. <button class='glossary-text'>Memory T cells</button> fulfill a similar function to memory <button class='glossary-text'>B cells</button>, mounting a fast and strong attack against previously detected specific antigens.

Due to the high number of B and T cells in the lymphoid organs, exposure to large amounts of foreign antigen can result in enlargement and even inflammation of these organs. Enlarged <button class='glossary-text'>lymph</button> nodes, especially in the neck region, may be detected by <button class='glossary-text'>palpation</button> (feeling with the fingers and hands) during a physical exam and are indicative of a possible infection. Chronic inflammation of the lymphoid organs may require surgical treatment. For example, due to their location in the back of the <button class='glossary-text'>pharynx</button>, the <button class='glossary-text'>tonsils</button> can make it hard to swallow or breathe if they become inflamed. In this case, the tonsils may be removed in a special procedure called a <button class='glossary-text'>tonsillectomy</button>.

Another organ of the <button class='glossary-text'>lymphatic system</button> that plays important roles in storing antibodies and removing old red blood cells from the <button class='glossary-text'>cardiovascular system</button> is the <button class='glossary-text'>spleen</button>. The spleen is made up primarily of <button class='glossary-text'>red pulp</button>, a structure designed to eliminate old red blood cells. Within this red pulp are small <button class='glossary-text'>lymph nodes</button> in areas called <button class='glossary-text'>white pulp</button>.

Antibodies (sometimes also referred to as <button class='glossary-text'>immunoglobulins</button>) are large Y-shaped proteins (see Figure 4) that are composed of two <button class='glossary-text'>heavy chains</button> and two <button class='glossary-text'>light chains</button>. The two “arms” of the antibody are capable of binding the specific  <button class='glossary-text'>antigen</button>. The tip of each arm is characterized by a specific protein structure, the <button class='glossary-text'>paratope</button>. The paratope recognizes a unique <button class='glossary-text'>protein sequence</button> (or <button class='glossary-text'>epitope</button>) in the structure of the antigen and binds to it. Binding will only take place if the paratope is exactly complementary to the epitope. This process is analogous to the key/lock principle, in that just as one key will only fit in one lock, so one paratope will recognize and bind to only one epitope. In this way, the <button class='glossary-text'>pathogen</button> is recognized by the other components of the immune system and eventually eliminated.

pageData.desc: Figure 4: Diagram showing an immunoglobulin (or antibody) and its composition of two heavy chains and two light chains
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Diagram showing an immunoglobulin (or antibody) and its composition of two heavy chains and two light chains

feedbackData.title: Feedback

pageData.subTitle: Detecting the Immune Response
pageData.text: The principle of the <button class='glossary-text'>specific immune response</button> has been utilized as a diagnostic tool both in research and healthcare. Several common <button class='glossary-text'>immunoassays</button> are based on this principle, including Western blotting, enzyme-linked immunoassay (<button class='glossary-text'>ELISAs</button>), and even over-the-counter pregnancy tests

In an ELISA, antibodies against a specific protein of interest (the ) are used to immobilize this protein onto a surface, forming an . The antibodies used in this step are called . After washing away any excess antibody that has not bound to the antigen, another antibody designed to detect and bind to the primary antibody is added. This is the . An enzyme can be attached (or conjugated) to the part of the secondary antibody that does not attach itself to the primary antibody. Now any secondary antibody molecules that have not bound to the primary antibody can be washed away. All of the secondary antibodies still present should therefore be indirectly bound to the antigen of interest. A substrate for the enzyme attached to the secondary antibody can now be added. This substrate is typically designed to undergo an (see Figure 5). Because unbound primary and secondary antibodies have been washed away, the enzyme-induced color change will only occur if the antigen is present. The color change can be detected either with the naked eye or with a specialized instrument.

pageData.desc: Figure 5: A diagram showing the schematic depiction of an ELISA reaction
pageData.altText: Figure 5: A diagram showing the schematic depiction of an ELISA reaction

pageData.text: The degree of color change can be directly correlated to the amount of antigen present, making the <button class='glossary-text'>ELISA</button> technique useful not only for detecting the presence of a specific antigen but also for quantifying that antigen. The resulting information can be useful in determining the number of cells of a particular <button class='glossary-text'>pathogen</button> that are present in a sample, for instance.

Primary antibodies can be either monoclonal or polyclonal. are more specific than . Monoclonal antibodies recognize only one specific on an antigen. This type of antibody is highly specific and will give the most accurate results. However, because they are more labor- and technology-intensive to produce, these antibodies are expensive. Polyclonal antibodies may recognize multiple epitopes on a given antigen. This can lead to false-positive results in cases in which one of the epitopes recognized is similar to an epitope found on proteins in other tissues or organisms. Polyclonal antibodies are simple to produce and are much less expensive than monoclonal antibodies.

ELISA kits are used to detect a number of viruses, such as the human immunodeficiency, West Nile, and influenza viruses. The food industry also uses ELISAs to test for the presence of certain <button class='glossary-text'>allergens</button>. Allergens are substances that induce allergic reactions in people sensitive to them. In an allergic reaction, the body mistakenly marks non-harmful materials as potential threats. The body will start the inflammation process and antibody production to eliminate the allergen, just as if the allergen was a pathogen. Examples of foods that contain allergens include milk, eggs, fish, shellfish, and nuts.

A simplified form of ELISA will only detect the presence of a specific protein or  <button class='glossary-text'>antigen</button>. This type of ELISA is very common in over-the-counter tests available at the pharmacy, such as those used for home pregnancy testing, for instance. Here, the presence of a pregnancy hormone called <button class='glossary-text'>human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)</button> is detected. The hormone hCG is produced after a fertilized egg has attached to the uterus wall and is normally detectable 6 days after the egg has been fertilized.
In this investigation, the will be used only to detect the presence of a substance that simulates a potential pathogen. As an example, artificial blood is used and the blood type is determined.

pageData.desc: This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. In Activity 1, you will prepare two Petri dishes of agarose. Next, add red and blue food dye to the first petri dish. Then, measure the distances each dye travels over 1 hour. Lastly, calculate the rate of diffusion of each dye.  In Activity 2, you will￼add synthetic blood and anti-sera to each Petri dish. Next, observe the dishes for precipitate formation over 1 hour and after 24 hours. Lastly, determine the blood type of each synthetic blood sample.
pageData.altText: This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. In Activity 1, you will prepare two Petri dishes of agarose. Next, add red and blue food dye to the first petri dish. Then, measure the distances each dye travels over 1 hour. Lastly, calculate the rate of diffusion of each dye.  In Activity 2, you will add synthetic blood and anti-sera to each Petri dish. Next, observe the dishes for precipitate formation over 1 hour and after 24 hours. Lastly, determine the blood type of each synthetic blood sample.

pageData.text: Read all of the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment, as described in the Safety and Procedure sections

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean up the work area and all glassware with soap and water after completing the investigation.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the sample with which you will conduct a simulated immunoassay in this investigation?
Which of the following best describes the way lymph moves through the lymphatic system?

options.text: Muscle contractions push lymph flow forward; valves prevent backward flow.
The heart pumps lymph forward; muscle contractions prevent backward flow.
Osmotic pressure pushes lymph flow forward and backward.
Lymph nodes push lymph flow forward and backward.
Lymph is a component of blood and moves as part of the circulatory system.

assestmentData.question: After resolving a bacterial infection, your body will mount a faster immune response if exposed to the same bacteria again because it identifies which of the following structures on the bacteria’s surface?
T lymphocytes and B lymphocytes are named for the locations in the body in which they mature. Which of the following describes “T” and “B”, respectively?
Which term is used for the part of an immunoglobulin that recognizes a specific protein sequence in an antigen?
Which cells specialize in secreting antibodies?
In an ELISA, the enzyme that will catalyze a color change if the antigen of interest is present is bound to which component of the assay?
Which of the following best describes monoclonal antibodies?

options.text: Monoclonal antibodies recognize only one specific epitope of an antigen.
Monoclonal antibodies are less labor-intensive to produce than polyclonal antibodies.
Monoclonal antibodies are commonly used as secondary antibodies in ELISA.
Monoclonal antibodies often generate false-positive results in ELISA.
Monoclonal antibodies are produced naturally in humans.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the defense mechanisms of the human immune system from least to most specific?

options.text: skin, innate immune response, adaptive immune response
innate immune response, ELISA, adaptive immune response
adaptive immune response, innate immune response, spleen

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the structure of an antibody?

options.text: A Y-shaped protein made of two heavy chains and two light chains.
A Y-shaped protein made of one variable region and two constant regions.
A ring-shaped protein made of one heavy chain and one light chain.
A ring-shaped protein made of an epitope and a paratope.
A T-shaped protein made of a spherical epitope.

Read the instructions.
Obtain all materials.
Clean and sanitize the work area.
If you choose to complete all three activities at the same time, ensure that all plate preparation is complete prior to adding any reagents to the agar plate.

In Activity 1, you will determine the rate of diffusion of food coloring as it moves through an agarose gel medium. During this activity, you will practice making the straight wells in the agarose gel required in Activity 2.

pages.title: Determining Rate of Diffusion (13 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
  Determining Rate of Diffusion (13 steps)

pageData.text: Place the Petri dish on a level surface.

To completely and thoroughly melt the agarose:
  1. Loosen, but do not remove, the cap of the agarose bottle.
  2. Using a microwave on medium, heat the agarose at 30-second intervals until the agarose is completely melted. The agarose will have no lumps and should pour easily.
Caution: The agarose will be very hot. Use an oven mitt or several layers of paper towels to protect your hands when you remove the agarose from the microwave.
1. Pour the melted agarose into the Petri dish; make sure all sections of the Petri dish are evenly covered.
1. Allow the agarose to cool completely, at least 20 min.
Repeat steps 1 and 2 for the second Petri dish.
Take a transfer pipet and squeeze the bulb to remove the air.
Gently push the pipet into the agar, making sure to slowly release the pressure on the bulb of the pipet. This will produce suction and prevent the agar from cracking.
Lift the pipet out vertically so as to produce straight wells as shown in the video. You have now created a well (Figure 6).

pageData.desc: Figure 6: Four wells in a Petri dish; the lower middle well contains red food coloring
pageData.altText: Figure 6: Four wells in a Petri dish; the lower middle well contains red food coloring

pageData.text: Repeat the procedure in the same Y section of the Petri dish until you have created 4 wells total. You may reuse the same transfer pipet as long as it can still generate suction.
Open the bottle of red food coloring, and carefully remove the dropper tip.
Using a needle-nose pipet, draw up a small amount of red food coloring.

Carefully empty the pipet into one of the wells. Note that the needle-nose pipets are easier to control more precisely if you squeeze the conical region above the stem and below the bulb when taking up and expelling liquid.
Using a fresh needle-nose pipet, repeat steps 9–10 with the blue food coloring for the second well.
Replace the cover on the petri dish and set the dish aside.

pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol
pageData.text: Measure the distance the food colorings travel through the agarose at 2, 5, 10, 30, and 60 minutes and record in Data Table 1.

In Activity 2, you will simulate immune reactions between blood and antisera by observing the formation of a precipitate between simulated blood samples and simulated antisera as they diffuse into one another in an agarose gel medium. You will then identify the blood type of each simulated blood sample.
Place the Petri dish on a level surface.
Turn the Petri dish over.

Use the grease pencil and mark the center of the second and third Y segments of the Petri dish
(dot 1 in Figure 7).
Using the ruler, measure out a distance of 1 cm from dot 1 and make a second dot with the grease pencil (dot 2).
Make two additional dots spaced 1 cm from dot 1; try to spread them out evenly, as illustrated in Figure 7.

pageData.desc: Figure 7: Illustration showing placement of four dots marked in one segment of a Petri dish
pageData.altText: Figure 7: Illustration showing placement of four dots marked in one segment of a Petri dish

pageData.text: Turn the Petri dish over.
Remove the lid.
Using a transfer pipet, cut a well over each dot.
Unscrew and remove the cap from synthetic blood Sample 1. Using a needle-nose pipet, fill the center well of the second segment with synthetic blood Sample 1.

Unscrew and remove the caps from the synthetic antisera. Using a fresh needle-nose pipet for each antiserum, fill the well in position 2 with anti A serum, well 3 with anti B serum, and well 4 with anti D serum.

Repeat steps 9 and 10 in the last segment of the Petri dish, using Sample 2 of synthetic blood and the three antisera. Be sure to use a fresh needle-nose pipet for the synthetic blood and for each antiserum.
Replace the cover and set the dish aside.
Repeat steps 1–12 in the second Petri dish with synthetic blood Samples 3 and 4.

pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol
pageData.text: Check for the formation of any precipitate between the central well and any of the surrounding wells. This precipitate can be seen as a thin white line inside the clear agarose halfway between the central well and the surrounding wells. This is done by holding the Petri dish over a dark surface while shining a flashlight through the Petri dish from the side. Check for precipitate formation after 10, 30, and 60 minutes and record your findings in Data Table 2 for Sample 1, Data Table 3 for Sample 2, Data Table 4 for Sample 3, and Data Table 5 for Sample 4. Optional: For best results, observe again after approximately 24 hours.

text: Dispose of all waste generated during the activity in the household trash.
Answer all of the discussion questions.

pageData.text: You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.
pageData.confirmationMessage: Are you sure you want to submit your work? You will not be able to edit the lab notebook after submitting your work.

pageData.altText: completion

pageData.title: Questions
text: What was the blood type for each of the synthetic blood samples? Explain your answers.

pageData.content: Figure 1. Major structures of the lymphatic system
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Illustration showing the lymphatic system and its components
Figure 2: Diagram showing the details of a lymphatic vessel

pageData.content: Figure 3. The parts of the spleen
pageData.altText: Figure 3: Illustration showing the anatomy of a lymph node and its components
Figure 4: Diagram showing an immunoglobulin (or antibody) and its composition of two heavy chains and two light chains

pageData.content: Figure 5. The steps of an ELISA
pageData.altText: Figure 5: A diagram showing the schematic depiction of an ELISA reaction

This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. In Activity 1, you will prepare two Petri dishes of agarose. Next, add red and blue food dye to the first petri dish. Then, measure the distances each dye travels over 1 hour. Lastly, calculate the rate of diffusion of each dye.  In Activity 2, you will add synthetic blood and anti-sera to each Petri dish. Next, observe the dishes for precipitate formation over 1 hour and after 24 hours. Lastly, determine the blood type of each synthetic blood sample.
Figure 6: Four wells in a Petri dish; the lower middle well contains red food coloring

pageData.content: Figure 7. Well placement in Petri dish compartment
pageData.altText: Figure 7: Illustration showing placement of four dots marked in one segment of a Petri dish

data.title: Adaptive immune system
data.content: The immunity that develops, and responds to a foreign substance or microorganism, after an infection or vaccination; also called the specific immune response

data.title: Allergens
data.content: Substances that induce an allergic reaction in people sensitive to them

data.title: Antigen
data.content: An outer-membrane protein which is specific to each type of microorganism and which is recognized by antibodies; also called antibody generators

data.title: Antigen-antibody complex
data.content: A complex formed by the binding of an antibody to an antigen in immunoassays

data.title: B lymphocytes (B cells)
data.content: A type of leukocyte (white blood cell) that makes antibodies; it is one of two types of leukocytes that are pre-programmed to bind to specific antigens via receptors embedded in their cell membranes

data.title: Cardiovascular system
data.content: A system of organs that includes the heart, blood vessels, and blood which is circulated throughout the body; also called the circulatory system

data.title: Clone
data.content: A genetically identical progeny cell

data.title: Cortex
data.content: Outer layer

data.title: Cytotoxic T cells
data.content: A type of T cell that directly attacks and destroys cells bearing foreign antigens on their surfaces, such as virus-infected cells or cancer cells

data.title: ELISA
data.content: A type of immunoassay used to detect and quantify a specific protein in a complex mixture; stands for enzyme-linked immunoassay

data.title: Enzyme-induced color change
data.content: A color change in immunoassays that will only occur if the antigen is present

data.title: Epithelial tissue
data.content: A type of tissue that covers all outer surfaces, and lines body cavities and hollow organs

data.title: Epitope
data.content: The part of an antigen that is recognized by the immune system; also called the protein sequence

data.title: GALT
data.content: A group of lymph nodes located in the gut; stands for gut-associated lymphoid tissue

data.title: Heavy chain
data.content: One of two “arms” of an antibody that are capable of binding a specific antigen; it consists of an antigen-binding portion having a variable region and a constant region

data.title: Human chorionic gonadotropin
data.content: A hormone that is produced after a fertilized egg has attached to the uterus wall and is normally detectable 6 days after the egg has been fertilized; abbreviated hCG

data.title: Immunoassay
data.content: A diagnostic tool both in research and healthcare that detects or measures antigens or antibodies

data.title: Immunoglobulins
data.content: Large Y-shaped proteins that bind to antigens

data.title: Innate immune system
data.content: The body's first line of defense against pathogens; also called the non-specific immune response

data.title: Leukocyte
data.content: An immune system cell; also called a white blood cell (WBC)

data.title: Light chain
data.content: One of two “arms” of an antibody that are capable of binding a specific antigen; it consists of an antigen-binding portion having a variable region and a constant region

data.title: Lymph
data.content: Colorless fluid containing white blood cells

data.title: Lymph node
data.content: An oval-shaped mass of tissue that filters the fluid running through it and removes contaminants

data.title: Lymphatic system
data.content: A system of tissues, vessels and organs that is part of the immune system and complementary to the circulatory system; also called the lymphoid system

data.title: MALT
data.content: A network of lymphoid cells and tissue; stands for mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue

data.title: Medulla
data.content: Inner region

data.title: Memory B cell
data.content: A type of B cell that persists for a long period of time; it enables a strong and rapid response if the same antigen enters the body again

data.title: Memory T cell
data.content: A type of T cell that persists for a long period of time; it enables a strong and rapid response if the same antigen enters the body again

data.title: Monoclonal antibodies
data.content: Highly specific antibodies that detect only one epitope on the antigen

data.title: Monocyte
data.content: A type of leukocyte (white blood cell) which, when stained, has blue-gray cytoplasm; it features U- or kidney-shaped nuclei and is the largest of all the leukocytes

data.title: Non-specific immune response
data.content: The body's first line of defense against pathogens; also called the innate immune system or response

data.title: Palpation
data.content: Feeling with the fingertips

data.title: Paratope
data.content: The tip of each antibody “arm”; it is characterized by a specific protein structure

data.title: Pathogen
data.content: A disease-causing microorganism or virus

data.title: Phagocytosis
data.content: The process of an immune cell engulfing pathogens and other foreign materials

data.title: Pharynx
data.content: The membrane-lined cavity behind the nose and mouth, connecting them to the esophagus; commonly referred to as the throat

data.title: Plasma cell
data.content: A type of B lymphocyte that secretes antigen-specific antibodies

data.title: Polyclonal antibodies
data.content: A mixture of antibodies produced by different B-cell clones within the same animal

data.title: Primary antibodies
data.content: The first antibodies used in forming the antigen-antibody complex in immunoassays

data.title: Protein sequence
data.content: The part of an antigen that is recognized by the immune system; also called the epitope

data.title: Red pulp
data.content: A structure found in the spleen that eliminates old red blood cells

data.title: Secondary antibody
data.content: An antibody designed to detect and bind to the primary antibody in an immunoassay

data.title: Skin
data.content: The outer covering of the body

data.title: Specific immune response
data.content: The immunity that develops, and responds to a foreign substance or microorganism, after an infection or vaccination; also called the adaptive immune system

data.title: Spleen
data.content: The ductless organ that is located in the left abdominal region near the stomach; it is involved in the production and removal of blood cells

data.title: T helper cell
data.content: A specialized T cell that recognizes the displayed antigen of a pathogen and stimulates the B cell to divide

data.title: T lymphocytes (T cells)
data.content: A white cell  that makes antibodies, one of two types of leukocytes that are pre-programmed to bind to specific antigens via receptors embedded in their cell membranes

data.title: Thymus
data.content: The organ located inferior to the thyroid gland and anterior to the heart; it belongs to the lymphatic, immune, and endocrine systems

data.title: Tonsillectomy
data.content: A surgical procedure to remove the tonsils; it is performed when the tonsils make it hard to swallow, breathe, or if they become inflamed

data.title: Tonsils
data.content: Two small masses of lymphoid tissue in the throat

data.title: White pulp
data.content: Small lymph nodes within the red pulp of the spleen
